Expectation1: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation1: The acquaintance encounters a person who is visibly upset and crying about a recent event.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I was chatting with Mia by the pool, trying to comfort her as she wiped away tears over her recent breakup. She needed someone to listen, and I wanted to be that supportive acquaintance, nodding and offering gentle words. But as I listened, I caught movement out of the corner of my eye—a group of teenagers was gathering at the deep end, laughing and edging dangerously close to the no-diving signs. My lifeguard instincts kicked in, and I felt the familiar pressure to enforce the rules, to keep everyone safe. But if I left Mia now, I’d seem cold and uncaring, maybe even make her feel abandoned in her vulnerable moment. My mind raced, torn between the expectation to be a compassionate friend and my duty to intervene before someone got hurt. I could feel my heart pounding, caught between two roles, each demanding my full attention at the same time.
